Peka hopes to do well in her business so that she can make improvements to her family's living standards and also be able to assist her partner of 5 years with their financial obligations.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, baking powder, cooking oil, vanilla, kitchen utensils, and plastic bags.

loans.name: Roseta

texts.en: Roseta is a 40-year-old single woman with 3 children. She runs a small tailoring business in her community. She has 2 years of experience with this business. Roseta has requested a loan to buy a new sewing machine, thread, needles, a measuring tape, a new pair of scissors and material. She plans to use her profits to pay for her children's education. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine, thread, needles, a measuring tape, a new pair of scissors and material.

loans.name: Tuiupu

texts.en: Tuiupu is a 19-year-old woman with one child. She plans to operate a small plantation business assisted by her partner of one year so that she will be able to help out in taking care of her family. That is why she has just joined the SPBD program in order to gain access to financial assistance. She plans to use this money to purchase bush knives, chemicals, a mist blower, fertilizers, vegetable seeds, and planting tools to further improve her plantation business. Tuiupu hopes to save a lot of her profit so that she will be able to improve the livelihood of her family.

loans.use: to purchase bush knives, chemicals, a mist blower, fertilizers, vegetable seeds, and planting tools.

loans.name: Rarotoga

texts.en: Rarotoga is a 27-year-old woman with 4 children. She has a vegetable garden and she sells vegetables to the members of her community.  She also delivers them around to the nearby shops, and she is assisted by her partner of 6 years. She has joined the SPBD program to gain access to financial assistance. She plans to use this money to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers, chemicals, a mist blower, and a spade for her business. Rarotoga hopes to earn a lot of savings from her profits so that she would be able to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers, chemicals, a mist blower, and a spade.

loans.name: Jaibalito Group

texts.en:
The small community of Jaibalito is located on the shores of beautiful Lake Atitlan in Guatemala. The population is mainly Mayan Kaqchiquel and works in various endeavors including agriculture, fishing and handicrafts. Recently, a Friendship Bridge Trust Bank called “Jaibalito” was formed by eight ladies. Their average age is 32 years old and they average 4 children. Only two members of the Trust Bank have had a formal education while the other six were unable to attend school.

Antonia is a single 20-year-old mother who cherishes her son. He is her motivation to live and prosper and she works very arduously each day. She had to figure out a way to support herself and her son and now creates beautiful beaded treasures including bracelets, necklaces and other beaded objects. As Antonia  lives in an area that attracts tourists, she has a clientele who are eager to buy her beaded creations. In addition, she has found a way to export her products and this motivates her even more. Antonia is requesting her very first loan to purchase additional supplies including a wider variety of beads in additional colors, needles and thread.

The ladies of the “Jaibalito” Trust Bank and Antonia look forward to their monthly meetings, not only to take care of their loan business but also to acquire personal and business tools. A Friendship Bridge Loan Officer brings the women new knowledge about health, hygiene and nutrition as well as women’s rights, discrimination and violence against women. They become more effective businesswomen with newly acquired business tools (customer service, pricing, marketing, accounting and budgeting). They also learn about self-esteem and leadership. Friendship Bridge calls the combination of the small loans and education “Microcredit Plus”. It is very effective!

Thank you, KIVA investors, for sharing your abundance by funding these much needed loans. The eight ladies of the “Jaibalito” Trust Bank, including Antonia, will reap tremendous benefits for themselves, their families and their community of Jaibalito.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies including a wider variety of beads in additional colors, needles and thread

loans.name: Utatlecas Group

texts.en:
“Utatlecas” meaning “Women from Santa Lucía Utatlán” is the name of the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank composed of eight hard-working and determined women in the Western Highlands of Guatemala. Santa Lucía Utatlán is a land where the population keeps their cultural and historical traditions alive.

Catarina, a 41-year-old member of the Trust Bank, has had three years of formal education, and has two children. Catarina sells chicken in a small stall in front of her house. Her business has been growing and she now caters for big events like anniversaries, birthdays and weddings. In order to expand her business, Catarina needs to inject additional capital and so she is requesting a new loan from Friendship Bridge that she will invest in more chickens. She wants to be certain to keep her business healthy and her clients satisfied. Catarina is very pleased that with her income, she is able to meet the educational expenses of her daughters. One of them is about to graduate with a teaching certificate and Catarina wants her to obtain even more education at university level.

The success of the women in the Trust Bank is due to their own determination as well as the tools that they gain in the “Microcredit Plus” Program of Friendship Bridge that combines the small loans and education. The ladies in the Trust Bank know that at each of their monthly meetings, they will gain practical business and personal tools from a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer. They learn about timely subjects like how to properly manage their businesses (budgeting, accounting, marketing, customer service, pricing) as well as the dangers of over-indebtedness. The women understand the importance of good nutritional practices and learn about health, hygiene and the use of medicinal plants. They also learn about women’s and children’s rights, violence against women and discrimination. 

Catarina and her friends in the “Utatlecas” Trust Bank are poised to step into a brighter future along with their family members and their community in the Guatemalan Highlands, but they are unable to walk into a local bank and secure a loan. KIVA investors fufill a most important part of the Friendship Bridge “Microcredit Plus” Program by supplying capital for these essential loans. Catarina and the ladies in the Trust Bank are most appreciative to each of you. Thank you!

loans.use: To buy more chickens, and to keep her business healthy and her clients satisfied

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is 18 years old and single with no children. 

She has a small plantation where she grows taro that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 1 year. 

Dorothy needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade. She joined SPBD this year to gain access to capital. 

Dorothy will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade

loans.name: Vaioalii

texts.en:
Vaioalii is a 61-year-old widow with 4 children. 

She joined the SPBD program to gain access to financial assistance and she has been a member for 4 years. She runs a small plantation business, selling her crops to the members of the community and also the traveling public. She also sells Samoan koko as another means of making money. 

She plans to use this loan to purchase chemicals and fertilizers for her business, timber and iron roofing for home improvements, and to pay school fees for her children's education. 

She hopes to expand her business in the future through saving most of her profits. Then she will be able to provide a better livelihood for her family.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, fertilisers, timber and iron roofing, and pay school fees

loans.name: Orquidea Group

texts.en:
From Western Guatemala, seven women have formed the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Orquideas” meaning “Orchids”. The ladies are focused to transform their lives through empowerment, small loans and education. They have a vision of raising their standard of living and creating a more prosperous future for themselves and their families.
 
Amelia is a married member of the Trust Bank. She is a 33-year-old teacher with two daughters, one of whom is about to graduate from high school. Amelia wants to continue to support her daughter so that she can continue her studies at university. Amelia has a traditional textile business and sells her merchandise both retail and wholesale. She sells the complete “traje” or traditional costume of blouse or heavier “huipil”, skirt, belt, and carrying cloth. She buys her merchandise at a wholesale price. Amelia is requesting a loan to diversify her merchandise with new styles and colors.

Although Amelia had access to a university education, she is quite pleased to participate in the educational components of the monthly meetings of the Trust Bank. She always learns something new and useful and sees how her fellow Trust Bank members enhance their lives and their businesses. The majority of the ladies do not know how to read or write and so the educational training sessions are essential to their success as caretakers of their family members and business entrepreneurs. The training is given in the indigenous language of the women, often with pictures, and covers a variety of subjects including effective business management practices, nutritional and health tools, and self-esteem.
 
The seven women of the “Orquideas” Trust Bank look forward to blooming just like the flowers that they are named after, and to creating a brighter tomorrow as empowered women eliminating poverty. KIVA investors are essential partners in this effort and highly valued. We will report on the progress of Amelia and the ladies in the Trust Bank in the very near future. Thank you, KIVA investors!

loans.use: To diversify her merchandise with new styles and colors, including skirts, belts, and carrying cloth.

loans.name: Rosario Fatima

texts.es:
Cada nuevo día es una oportunidad para seguir progresando y doña Rosario da lo mejor de sí para que esto se haga realidad. Es una señora amable y trabajadora de 49 años de edad, quien desde hace ocho años comercializa cosméticos en su comunidad. Ella está muy agradecida con Kiva y MiCrédito por el apoyo que le han brindado, con el crédito anterior logró aumentar su inventario y al mismo tiempo sus ingresos. Es una mujer que sabe administrar su negocio y brindar atención de calidad a su clientela para alcanzar el éxito.
Rosario solicita un segundo crédito para incrementar la producción de su capital, requiere comprar cremas para el cuerpo, tratamientos capilares y faciales; también cosmético como labiales, sombras, delineadores, entre otros. Se siente comprometida con su negocio y anhela que este siga en auge, razón principal por la que deposita su confianza en el financiamiento. Su mano derecha lo ha sido su hija, juntas luchan para lograr mejorar la economía familiar. Uno de sus planes futuros es establecer una tienda en su casa para lograr posicionar más productos.
texts.en:
Every day is a new opportunity to progress in life and Rosario does the best she can so that this will happen. Rosario is 49 years old, friendly and hard-working. She has been selling cosmetics in her community for eight years and is very grateful to Kiva and "MiCredito" for the support that they have provided. Rosario used her last loan to increase stock and, at the same time, her income. Rosario knows how to manage her business and provide good-quality service to her customers in order to be successful.

Rosario is applying for a second loan in order to increase capital. Rosario needs to buy body creams, hair and facial treatments, and make-up, such as lipsticks, eye-shadow, eyeliner and more. Rosario is dedicated to her business and wants it to continue growing and so trusts that her loan will help with this. Rosario's daughter is her right-side-woman in all of this. Together, mother and daughter fight to improve the family economy. One of Rosario's plans for the future include opening a store in her house in order to sell more products.

loans.use: to buy body creams, hair and facial treatments, and make-up, such as lipsticks, eye-shadow, eyeliner and more.

loans.name: Rejina

texts.es: La señora Rejina vive y trabaja en Colomi, económicamente es independiente, trabajadora y responsable; tiene una tienda de barrio en la cual vende muchos productos de mayor rotación, también se dedica a la agricultura, siembra papa, haba, oca  y papaliza como los principales productos en terrenos propios en el mismo lugar, tiene una experiencia de 40 años en el sector agrícola, además cuenta con cabezas de ganado 2 de engorde y 3 lecheras. Actualmente requiere un crédito para la compra de mercadería para su tienda de barrio, compra de 8 cargas de semilla de papa y  1 camión de abono orgánico, ya que quiere aumentar más productos para su tienda y  proveerse de insumos  agrícolas porque se acerca la época de siembra, de esta forma incrementará su producción  y tendrá mayores ventas que mejorarán su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Rejina lives and works in Colomi. She is economically independent, hard-working and responsible. She has a neighbourhood store where she sells many daily products. 

She also works in agriculture, planting mostly potatoes, beans, yams and papa lisa in her own land in the same location. She has 40 years of experience in agriculture. She also has cattle: 2 for meat and 3 dairy. 

Currently she needs a loan to buy stock for her neighbourhood store and buy 8 loads of seed potatoes and 1 truck of organic fertilizer, because she wants to increase the number of products in her store and provide herself with agricultural supplies because the sowing season is approaching. 

In this way, she will increase her production and she will make more sales which will improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy groceries for her neighbourhood store and to stock organic fertilizer

loans.name: Bertha Lucia

texts.es: Bertha está separada de su esposo, ella se quedo sola a cargo de su hija de 16 años y su hijo de 17 años mismos que están estudiando, Bertha paga arriendo por un local para exhibir su mercadería en ropa, ya que  de este negocio paga todos los gastos de vivienda, alimentación, educación entre otros gastos de sus hijos, Bertha necesita el crédito para comprar más mercadería, su aspiración es atraer más clientela y así que su negocio sea más rentable y terminar de educar a sus hijos.
texts.en: Bertha is separated from her husband, and she is now alone in caring for her 16-year-old daughter and 17-year-old son, both of whom are in school. Bertha pays rent for a space to show her clothing merchandise, since this business pays all the expenses of housing, food, education, and other expenses for her children. Bertha needs this loan to buy more merchandise. Her aspiration is to attract more clients, so her business can be more profitable and she can finish educating her children.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Nanci Carolina

texts.es:
Nanci es una joven de 19 años de edad, está soltera y vive con sus padres, actualmente estudia los fines de semana el bachillerato.
 

Ella desde muy pequeña, se ha dedicado a la venta de tamales de gallina y elotes en la comunidad, también realiza ventas de refrescos, panes, golosinas y bebidas gaseosas en la cancha de futbol cuando hay partidos, todo esto lo realiza junto a su madre pues de ella aprendió los diversos trabajos. Nanci también obtiene ingresos de cuidar un niño de un vecino, con lo cual ayuda en el hogar y cubre sus gastos de estudios.
 
Ella necesita el crédito para comprar más bebidas gaseosas y para comprar más insumos para elaborar los tamales. El crédito le servirá de mucho ya que no cuenta con capital de trabajo.


El principal sueño de Nanci es que en su negocio le vaya muy bien porque de esto depende mucho que ella pueda finalizar los estudios que realiza los fines de semana, y si Dios se lo permite espera buscar un empleo formal y luego seguir estudiando una carrera universitaria.
texts.en:
Nanci is 19 years old, single and lives with her parents. She is currently studying for her high school degree at the weekends.

Since a young age, Nanci has made a living selling chicken and corn tamales in the local community. She also sells soft drinks, breads, sweets and fizzy drinks at the local football pitch when there is a match. Nanci does all of this work alongside her mother, from whom she learned how to run this business. Nanci also makes money babysitting a neighbour's son. This helps to pay bills at home and cover the cost of her studies.

Nanci needs this loan in order to buy fizzy drinks and more supplies for making tamales. This loan will be a great help as Nanci does not have working capital.

Nanci's biggest dream is for her business to go well. She depends on it greatly and, with it, she can finish her studies and, God willing, find a job in the formal market and then continue to study for a university degree.

loans.use: to buy fizzy drinks and more supplies for making tamales. This loan will be a great help as Nanci does not have working capital.

loans.name: Las Llovisnas Group

texts.en:
Friendship Bridge, a non-governmental organization in Guatemala, offers a combination of small loans and participatory education (Microcredit Plus) to over 21,000 women who share the common goals of eliminating poverty and empowering themselves. 

Estrella is one of these women who just finished her formal education. This single, 20-year-old was unable to obtain employment and decided to look for ways to start her own business and generate income for her family. For many years, her family members have created beautiful textiles and Estrella learned this skill at a very young age. She decided to join the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Las Lloviznas”, meaning “The Sprinkles”, in order to obtain capital to inject into the family textile business.  She is on her second loan cycle and will use her loan to purchase supplies including needles, various colors of thread, lace and other necessities to fabricate beautiful, traditional blouses. She wants to be certain to satisfy the desires of her clients and generate enough income to continue with her university studies, which is her ultimate dream!

Estrella shares that the educational program of Friendship Bridge has enabled her to enhance her business administration skills. She is better equipped to manage her loan and her business with newly acquired business knowledge (budgeting, accounting, customer service, marketing, pricing). She is ready to meet the possible challenges of her daily life with information about women’s rights, discrimination, violence against women as well as the importance of self-esteem. Estella and the ladies in the Trust Bank are more knowledgeable about the health of themselves and their families with new insights into nutrition, hygiene and the use of medicinal plants. 

The small loans and education transform lives, families and communities. Kiva investors are greatly valued for their kindness and generosity in providing capital for the loans. We shall update you on Estella and the women of “Las Lloviznas” Trust Bank in a future report! Thank you, Kiva investors!

loans.use: To purchase needles, thread, lace and other necessities to fabricate beautiful, traditional blouses.

loans.name: Taiaina

texts.en: Taiaina is a 26-year-old single lady who wants to help with her family's financial obligations by operating a small plantation business selling to the members of her community and to the traveling public. She has just joined the SPBD program to gain access to financial assistance. With this money, she plans to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, bush knives and blade sharpeners for the better improvement of her plantation. Taiaina hopes to save a lot of her profits so that she is able to budget and provide for her family's weekly essential needs.

loans.use: To purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, bush knives, and blade sharpners

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Since 1991, Richard has been a driving instructor working to make our roads safe one new driver at a time. He began working as an employee for a large local driving school, but found that while he was focused on imprinting students with the safest possible driving habits, his employers were more focused on extracting payments from their customers as quickly as possible.

After seeing the shortcomings in how others run their businesses, Richard decided it was his time to try to start his own student-centric driving school. His school focused on providing a superlative level of customer service while ensuring that graduates of the program demonstrated the highest level of safety and conscientiousness on the road.

Richard is quick to point out how much harder it would have been to start and maintain his business without his loan from Accion. He used his loan money to consolidate two outstanding loans he had for a total monthly savings of about $500, freeing up crucial capital for business start-up costs.

Richard is keen to see his business grow in the future. He hopes one day to hire additional instructors so that he can service multiple clients simultaneously, and he has an extremely qualified candidate picked out to act as President/CEO once the opportunity is there.

Most of all, Richard wants his business exemplify the driving instruction industry’s best practices. His hopes for the future are to create jobs, take care of students and “pay forward” the opportunity that Kiva lenders have so generously provided him.

loans.use: to consolidate two outstanding loans

loans.name: Lesina

texts.en: Lesina is a 47-year-old married woman with five children. She runs a rather large plantation business assisted by her husband and children. She has been with the SPBD program for more than four years and she has now moved on to her second SME cycle loan, which reflects how well she is doing in her business. She plans to use this money to purchase a second hand pickup, fertilizers and vegetable seeds to help with the better improvement of her business. Lesina has managed to improve her family's standard of living due to her commitment to trying to provide a better life for them through working really hard and continuing the good productivity of her plantation.

loans.use: To purchase a second hand pickup, fertilizers and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Mayluna

texts.en: Mayluna is a businesswoman from Mahayag. She is 31 years old, married and has expertise in selling. She runs a little sari-sari store and earns a meager income that sufficiently supports her family. Mayluna is a full-fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. She maintains her membership in good standing without records of default. Now, she applied for a loan to restock her store with basic commodities and other consumable items. Mayluna continues to look for better business opportunities, proof that she has the passion and the energy to make ends meet for her family.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities and other consumable items

loans.name: Fitu

texts.en: Fitu is a 27-year-old single mother with one child. She runs her barbeque business in the village selling to the members of her community and the traveling public. She has been a member of the SPBD program for two years now, gaining access to financial assistance. She plans to use this money to purchase two toilet bowls, bricks, cement, timber, and iron roofing for her home improvement. Fitu has managed to improve her family's living standards with the income she has earned from her business, hopes to continue to prosper in this venture and will look into other ways of earning money in the future.

loans.use: To purchase toilet bowls, bricks, cement, timber, and iron roofing

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a Babban Gona farmer from Ang/Kunda. Samaila expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Samaila to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Samaila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Samaila is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Samaila will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Samaila will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sara Luz

texts.es: Sara es una joven emprendedora, con mucho deseo de superar, es madre soltera, su hijo estudia educación primaria  por quien trabaja y nanhela mejorar su futuro; para ella no es tan fácil el poder decir voy a estudiar, pues primero tiene que contar con los recursos necesarios para lograr su objetivo es por ello que solicita este crédito para pagar el titulo en la Carrera de Ciencias de la educación en Biología, llegar a este punto es para ella un logro que con esfuerzos propios pudo realizar y que finalizaría con este crédito que desde ya agradece a Kiva por el apoyo.  Su mayor sueño es aplicar sus conocimientos en una empresa con mayor remuneración para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Sara is a young entrepreneur with a great desire to get ahead. She is a single mother. Her son is in primary school and it is for him that she works and dreams to make his future better.

For her, it is not so easy to say "I am going to study", for she first needs to have the necessary resources to achieve her objective. This is why she is requesting this loan, to pay the fees for her Science Degree in Biology. 

She managed to get to this point through her own efforts and would be able to complete her plans with this credit. She now thanks Kiva for the support.  Her greatest dream is to apply her knowledge in a company with higher pay to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees

loans.name: Ivoga

texts.en: Ivoga is a 30-year-old married woman with no children. She wants to start a pancake business to help out in taking care of her family's weekly essential needs. She is planning to sell them to the members of her community. That is why she has just joined the SPBD program in order to gain access to financial assistance. She plans to use this money to purchase cooking oil, sugar, flour, baking powder, large pots and pans and large buckets for her pancake business. Ivoga hopes to save a lot of profit so that not only would she help out in her family's financial obligations for the week, but also to reinvest it back into her business for it to be a continuous venture.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, sugar, flour, baking powder, large pots and pans and large buckets  for her pancake business.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Iliya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Grace, and Reuben ,. Iliya is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Iliya will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Iliya can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Iliya is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ulfridis

texts.es:
Ulfridis tiene 47 años de edad, está casado y es un hombre muy trabajador, él aprendió a trabajar en la albañilería, además trabaja en la agricultura y lo aprendió al lado de su padre, esta actividad le ha permitido sostener a sus hijos y esposa.

Ulfridis cuenta con 30 años de experiencia de trabajar en la agricultura y a pesar de los problemas que se está dando con las siembras Ulfridis sigue adelante con los cultivos. 


El crédito lo solicitó para comprar abono para su milpa ya que necesita aplicarlo por segunda vez.

Ulfridis espera que mejore la situación climática para que la milpa se desarrolle bien.
texts.en:
Ulfridis, 47, is married and is a hardworking man. He learned to work as a mason and works also in agriculture. His father taught him this activity, which has helped him to maintain his children and wife.

Ulfridis has worked in agriculture for thirty years and despite the problems he has had with his crops, he has managed to get ahead with his activity.

He requested a loan to buy fertilizer to spread it for the second time over his plantation.

Ulfridis hopes that the weather conditions improve in order to have a good harvest.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and spread it for the second time over his plantation.

loans.name: Isidoro

texts.es: El Sr. Isidoro trabaja para una Institución del Estado, con el crédito anterior construyó una habitación para sus hijos quienes son menores de edad, por lo que expresa estar muy agradecido con Afodenic y Kiva por esta gran oportunidad que muchas personas como él necesitan para poder brindar mejores condiciones a su familia.  Solicita este crédito para poner cerámica en la parte de la sala de su Vivienda que actualmente es de cemento y con esta mejora dara mayor realce a su vivienda y gozara de mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Isidoro works for a governmental institution. With the previous loan, he built a room for his children, who are underage. He says that he is very grateful to AFODENIC and Kiva for such an opportunity, something that many like him need in order to improve their family’s living conditions.

He is requesting a loan to tile the floor of his living room, which is made of cement. This will improve the way the house looks and his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy floor tiles and pay for the labor.

loans.name: Ishaku

texts.en: Ishaku is a Babban Gona farmer from Makera. Ishaku is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Ishaku to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaku can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Ishaku is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Ishaku is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Ishaku will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs so she can once again attend to her coffee plantation.

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es:
Vicenta tiene 31 años de edad, está acompañada y su pareja se dedica a la albañilería, tienen 4 hijos, de los cuales 3 están cursando educación básica y el más pequeño se queda en casa con ella.


Desde hace 12 años, Vicenta se ha dedicado al comercio, oficio que lo aprendió  a lado  de su madre realizando la venta de ropa, productos cosméticos y la venta de alimentos, esta experiencia le dio la idea  de poner una tienda en su casa y por las tardes vende papas fritas, pupusas, pasteles, enchiladas, etc.  



Vicenta necesita el crédito para invertir en su  negocio, comprará 2 estantes, una cocina adecuada para las papas fritas y pasteles, y lo que le sobre lo utilizará para comprar maíz y materia prima para la elaboración de comida rápida.
 

En un futuro ella planea tener su negocio fortalecido para dar una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos y sobretodo  enseñarles que con esfuerzo y trabajo pueden alcanzar cualquier meta que  se tracen.
texts.en: Vicenta, 31, is in a common-law relationship and her partner is a bricklayer.  They have four children; three are enrolled in basic education, and the youngest stays at home with her.  For twelve years, Vicenta has been engaged in business, a trade she learned while selling clothing, cosmetics, and food at her mother’s side.  This experience gave her the idea of setting up a store in her home and, in the afternoons, she sells French Fries, “pupusas” [stuffed tortillas], cakes, and enchiladas, etc. Vicenta needs the loan to invest in her business.  She will purchase two shelves, a suitable kitchen for making the French Fries and cakes, and she will use the remainder to purchase corn and basic ingredients to make fast food. In the future, she plans to strengthen her business in order to provide her children with a better quality of life and, above all, teach them that with hard work and effort they can achieve any goal they set.

loans.use: to purchase two shelves, a suitable kitchen for making the French Fries and cakes, and she will use the remainder to purchase corn and basic ingredients to make fast food.

loans.name: Luis Alonso

texts.es:
Luis tiene 49 años de edad, es un hombre trabajador que desde temprana edad tuvo que dedicarse de lleno a la vida laboral, solo pudo cursar segundo grado debido a la guerra civil que se desató en el país, está casado y su esposa realiza los oficios del hogar, tiene 7 hijos pero solamente  cuatro viven con él porque los demás emigraron e USA.

Luis se dedica a la agricultura, él cultiva maíz, frijol y sorgo, también trabaja con ganado ya que posee unas vacas que le proporcionan leche y derivados para el consumo familiar, siendo su padre quien le enseñó las actividades que ahora realiza.


El préstamo lo necesita para comprar una vaca, el resto lo utilizará para insumos agrícolas  (fertilizantes, productos fitosanitarios, entre otros), con esta ayuda Luis tendrá la posibilidad de invertir para mejorar sus condiciones económicas.

Su sueño es poder establecer un hato ganadero donde participen todos los miembros de su familia y que sea  rentable para el sustento de esta.
texts.en:
Luis, 49, is a hardworking man who had to work since he was very young. He could only study up to the second grade due to the civil war. He is married. His wife works as a housewife and he has seven children, but only four live with him because the rest migrated to the United States.

Luis works in agriculture. He grows corn and sorghum and has cows that give him and his family milk and other products. His father taught him these activities.

He needs a loan to buy a cow. He will use the remainder to buy agricultural supplies such as fertilizers and pesticides. With this help, he will be able to invest and improve his financial situation.

His dream is to own a cattle ranch together with his family and be able to sustain it.

loans.use: to buy a cow and agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Mustapha

texts.en: Mustapha remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Mustapha, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. "With access to high quality inputs, mustapha can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income". “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Mustapha.  With this loan, Mustapha is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Bako Nuhu

texts.en: Bako Nuhu is a Babban Gona farmer from Chinoo. Bako Nuhu expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Bako Nuhu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Bako Nuhu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Bako Nuhu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Bako Nuhu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Bako Nuhu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hussaini

texts.en: Hussaini remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Hussaini, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Hussaini is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Hussaini. With this loan, Hussaini is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Sarah, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. "With access to high quality inputs, Sarah can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.".  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Sarah   With this loan, Sarah is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Rev. Bitrus

texts.en: Rev. Bitrus remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Rev. Bitrus, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rev. Bitrus is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”, expressed Rev. Bitrus. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Michael joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Omega, Kefas, and  Ezrah. Michael is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Michael will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Michael can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Michael is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long-term goal is to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Yusuf Nomau

texts.en: Yusuf Nomau is a 43-year-old farmer from Ang/Rukku.  As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf Nomau is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf Nomau can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf Nomau is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Yusuf Nomau is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Simon,  and  Hosea. Yusuf Nomau’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Ibrahim Magaji

texts.en: Ibrahim Magaji is a maize farmer from Ang/Rukku.  As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim Magaji is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ibrahim Magaji can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Ibrahim Magaji is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Ibrahim Magaji is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Manuel De Jesús

texts.es:
Manuel tiene 37 años de edad, es un hombre muy trabajador, por motivos económicos no pudo seguir estudiando, tan solo logró cursar segundo año de educación básica, está casado y su esposa atiende una tienda y realiza los quehaceres del hogar, tiene 4 hijos, tres estudian y uno trabaja ayudando le con las actividades agrícolas.


Manuel siempre ha trabajado en la agricultura, tanto en lo propio como en lo ajeno, su jornada es de 5:00 am a 1:00 pm, en las tardes recolecta leña y cuida un par de cerdos que tiene engordando, su hijo mayor es de gran ayuda en su trabajo.


Él necesita el crédito para comprar de fertilizantes, pues tiene cultivo de maíz y ya está en la etapa para fertilizarlo, y en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para la compra, por ello ha decidido realizar el préstamo y así, su cultivo se desarrollará adecuadamente.

Su sueño es que sus hijos puedan estudiar en la universidad, convirtiéndose en unos verdaderos profesionales, porque al prepararse podrán tener mayores oportunidades en la vida.
texts.en:
Manuel, 37, is a very hardworking man.  For financial reasons he wasn't able to keep attending school; he only managed to finish the second year of basic education.  He's married and his wife runs a store and takes care of the home.  He has four children; three are in school and one helps with the basic farming tasks.

Manuel has always worked in agriculture, both on his own and for others.  His workday is from 5 a.m. until 1 p.m.  In the afternoon he collects firewood and takes care of a couple of pigs he's fattening.  His oldest son is a big help in his work.

He needs the loan to buy fertilizers because it's time to fertilize his cornfield.  Currently he doesn't have the money he needs; he decided to request the loan so his crop will grow properly.

His dream is for his children to be able to go to college and become true professionals, because they'll have better opportunities in life.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Tanumia

texts.en: Tanumia is a 32-year-old unwed woman with 3 children. She runs a small fishing business in her community to earn a living. She has 1 year of experience with this business. Tanumia needs a loan to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Tanumia has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles.

loans.name: Daniel Bawa

texts.en: Daniel Bawa is a 49-year-old farmer from Ang/Rukku.  As a Babban Gona member, Daniel Bawa is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Daniel Bawa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Daniel Bawa is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Daniel Bawa is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Hosea,  and  Mathew. Daniel Bawa’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Ana Rose

texts.en: Ana Rose, 33, is married with three children. Her major source of income is buying and selling grocery items. She has been in this business for 6 years already. The business has helped her meet her family's financial needs, especially the education of her children. She is still continuing the business because it provides a good income due to her loyal customers. Her plan is to maintain her inventory so that her customers will be served well. She is still planning for a business expansion for the good of her children. She has already taken advantage of loans previously to purchase additional inventory, and now she is re-applying for another loan for her store.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery items for her grocery store.

loans.name: Sona's Group

texts.fr:
En entamant ce neuvième cycle, ce banc villageois créé en Mai 2010 regroupe des  femmes très actives dans les marchés : marché central et marché de quartier. Elles sont toutes issues du même quartier et ont une bonne entente entre elles. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Sona (assise à l’extrême droite avec la main gauche levée) est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe,  âgée de 51 ans, elle est mariée. Elle est vendeuse de légume au marché du quartier, elle fait aussi de l’agriculture vivrière durant la saison des pluies. Elle s’approvisionne au marché central ou au grand marché international pour la revente au détail dans son marché de quartier.

Avec ce nouveau crédit, elle envisage d’acheter trois sacs de patates douce, deux sacs de manioc, 10 kg de poivre, des paquets de bouillon pour la revente.

Avec les bénéfices, elle compte appuyer son mari dans les frais d’entretien de la maison réalisation de clôture, équipement des toilettes, mais aussi dans l’alimentation familiale.
texts.en: This "banc villageois" on its ninth loan cycle was created in May 2010. It consists of women who are very active in the central market and the neighborhood market. They all come from the same neighborhood and get along well.  Their main activity is small business.  Ms. Sona (sitting at the far right with her left hand raised) is the representative of this group. She is 51 years old and married. She sells vegetables at the neighborhood market. She also engages in farming during the rainy season.  She buys her supplies at the central market or at the large international market for resale at her neighborhood market.  With this new loan, she plans to buy 3 bags of sweet potatoes, 2 bags of manioc, 10 kg of pepper, and some packets of bouillon for resale.  With the profits, she plans to help her husband with their home maintenance costs, fence construction, toilet installation, and also feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy 3 bags of sweet potatoes, 2 bags of manioc, 10 kg of pepper, and some packets of bouillon.

loans.name: Bazarkan

texts.ru: Базаркан 48 лет, замужем, мать 3 детей. В поиске источника доходов для своей семьи Базаркан стала заниматься полеводством и животноводством. Бизнес начала в 1995 году с покупки 8 коз. Благодаря ее непосильному труду и емкой работе Базаркан достигла хороших успехов в работе и стала получать ежемесячную прибыль в сумме 7,000 сом(KGS) от реализации кукурузы, молока и молочной продукции, также Базаркан продает сузмо и курут, который делает вручную вместе со своим мужем. В обороте на данный момент есть 100 кг. курута и 150 кг. сузмо. На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве Базаркан имеется: 5 дойных коров и 20 овец. Также в наличии есть земельный надел на обработку и посадку кукурузы. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Базаркан обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS), который она направит на производство курута с целью дальнейшей его перепродажи. Она считает это выгодным вложением, так как приготовленный вручную из экологически чистых продуктов, домашнего молока, курут, пользуется большим спросом, как среди местных жителей, так и среди туристов. Базаркан является одним из трех участников группы "Замира". Доходы от кредита Базаркан планирует вложить в дальнейшее развитие своего небольшого бизнеса.
texts.en:
Bazarkan is 48 years old, married and is the mother of three children. In search of a source of income for her family, Bazarkan began practicing crop farming and livestock breeding. This business was started in 1995 with a purchase of 8 goats. Thanks to Bazarkan's back-breaking labor and intensive work, she was able to achieve lots of successes in her work. She began to receive an average monthly income of 7,000 som (KGS) from the sale of corn, milk and dairy products. Bazarkan also sells suzmo (sour cream cheese) and kurut (dried sour cream cheese, rolled into balls), which she and her husband make by hand. They currently have 100 kilograms of kurut and 150 kilograms of suzmo in circulation. Bazarkan currently has 5 dairy cows and 20 sheep on her farm. She also has on hand a plot of land on which she cultivates and plants corn on.

For the further development of her business, Bazarkan turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 40,000 som (KGS) which she will spend on the production of kurut to then later resell. She considers this a profitable investment, as the handmade production of eco-friendly products like local milk and kurut is in high demand amongst local residents and tourists alike. Bazarkan is one of three member of the group "Zamira." Bazarkan plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further development of her small business.

loans.use: to hand-make kurut (dried sour cream cheese, rolled into balls) for future sale.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en: Gabriel is a Maize farmer from Ang/Tafki.  As a Babban Gona member, Gabriel, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Gabriel can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Gabriel is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Gabriel is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Ezekiel, and  Zainab,. Gabriel’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Yohana

texts.en: Yohana remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Yohana, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yohana  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Yohana. With this loan, Yohana is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Pedro Ismael

texts.es: El señor Pedro siempre dedicado a su trabajo, desde siempre a trabajado la tierra herencia que sus padres le han dejado, en la actualidad tiene cosecha de Aguacate, Guayaba y Piña las cuales requieren de mantenimiento, con este crédito el comprara: 5 qq de Urea, 5 qq de Completo, 2 lts de Herbicida, 10 lts de refrescante Byfolar, 4 lts de Cipermetrina, 2 lts de Tigre ( para Guayaba). con este mantenimiento que realizara el señor Pedro evitara la maleza en el cultivo y la llegada de Plagas que destruyen el fruto. Muy agradecido don Pedro con Kiva y Afodenic por el apoyo que le han brindado con estos financiamientos.
texts.en:
Pedro is committed to his work, he has always cultivated the land that he inherited from his parents. At the present time he has crops of avocado, guava, and pineapple which need care. 

With this loan he will buy five quintals of Urea, five quintals of Completo, two liters of herbicide, 10 liters of Byfolar [foliar fertilizer], four liters of cypermethrin, two liters of Tigre [insecticide] (for the guava). With this maintenance work that he will carry out, Pedro will avoid the weeds in the crops and the arrival of pests that destroy the fruit. 

Pedro is very grateful to Kiva and AFODENIC for the support they have given him with these loans.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Salimata's Group

texts.fr:
En entamant ce neuvième cycle, ce banc villageois créé en Mai 2010 regroupe des  femmes très actives dans les marchés : marché central et marché de quartier. Elles sont toutes issues du même quartier et ont une bonne entente entre elles. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Salimatou (debout à l’extrême droite avec la main droite levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe,  âgée de 52 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 02 filles. Elle est vendeuse de pâte d’arachide et d’huile de palme qu’elle achète auprès de femmes productrices pour la revente à la capitale et dans les régions du centre. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité pour l’avoir pratiqué pendant plus de 15 ans.

Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter  au niveau du marché international 08 seaux de pâte d’arachide de 20 kg et 02 bidons de 20 litres d’huile de palme pour la revente. 

Apres vente et déduction des frais de transport, les bénéfices  nets lui serviront d’une part à accroître son épargne et d’autre part à soutenir son mari dans la construction de leur maison.
texts.en: This "banc villageois" on its ninth loan cycle was created in May 2010. It consists of women who are very active in the central market and the neighborhood market. They all come from the same neighborhood and get along well.  Their main activity is small business.  Ms. Salimatou (standing at the far right with her hand raised) is the representative of this group. She is 52 years old, married, and mother of two girls. She sells peanut butter and palm oil that she buys from female producers for resale in the capital and in the central regions. She has good experience in this business from engaging in it for over 15 years.  With this new loan, she plans to buy at the international market eight 20-kg buckets of peanut butter and two 20-liter containers of palm oil for resale.  After sales and deducting transport costs, the net profit will help her increase her savings and help her husband with the construction of their home.

loans.use: to buy eight 20-kg buckets of peanut butter and two 20-liter containers of palm oil.

loans.name: Bubuazhar

texts.ru: Бубуажар 63 года, замужем, мать 4 детей. Образование-среднее. Дети все взрослые и самостоятельные, живут отдельно, по хозяйству помогает супруг. С 1994 года занимается сельским хозяйством- животноводством, начав этот бизнес с покупки одного теленка. Ежемесячный доход на сегодняшний день составляет около 10,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Бубуажар, на сегодняшний день она имеет хорошее хозяйство: 3 коровы, 20 овец. Прибыль позволила Бубуажар размножить скот в домашнем хозяйстве и тем самым улучшить семейное благосостояние. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Бубуажар обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец и корма для скота. Доходы от кредита Бубуажар планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества скота, а также сделать ремонт дома.
texts.en: Bubuazhar is 63 years old, married and a mother to four children. She has a secondary education. All of her children are grown-up and self-sufficient. They live separately. Bubuazhar's husband helps her with her farm. Since 1994, she has been working in farming, specifically livestock breeding. She started this business with the purchase of one calf. Her current monthly income is about 10,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Bubuazhar's hard work, she currently has a great farm with 3 cows and 20 sheep. This income allowed Bubuazhar to breed her cattle on her small farm and thereby improving her family's living conditions. For the further development of her business, Bubuazhar turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 50,000 som (KGS) to buy sheep and cattle feed. Bubuazhar plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to renovate her house.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and cattle feed.

loans.name: Suleman

texts.en: Suleman remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Suleman, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Suleman is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Suleman. With this loan, Suleman is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Eli

texts.en:
Eli remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Eli, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. With access to high quality inputs such as fertilizer and urea, Eli can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
“In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs,” expressed Eli. With this loan, Eli is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en: Haruna is a Babban Gona farmer from Makera. Haruna expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Haruna to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Haruna can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Haruna is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Haruna will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Haruna will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Las Tejedoras De Choabaj Group

texts.es:
Durante 12 años la gente que vive en Chichiscatenango ha gustado de  buena compra de ropa típica adornada con los más vivos colores  en casa de doña María, soltera y de 38 años ( en la foto primera de la izquierda).

Su hogar se llena del ruido de sus dos hijos menores de edad y con la bulla de la gente que llega a comprar con doña María, hay para que escoger por la variedad de colores y ropa de todo precio y tamaño.

Es tanta la gente que llega a comprarle que el espacio en su domicilio ya es demasiado pequeño para el negocio.  Por lo tanto ha decidido integrarse a un grupo de mujeres con el mismo impulso comercial de buscar un amplio mercado para sus trajes.

Razón por la cual ha solicitado un crédito  para la compra de hilos y  otros materiales, así poder seguir manteniendo sus sueños como negociante y sostenedora de su familia.
texts.en:
For 12 years the people who live in Chichiscatenango have enjoyed buying the most brightly coloured traditional clothing from the home of Doña Maria. Maria is 38 years old and single. In the photo she is the first from the left.

Her home is full of the noise made by her two children, who are under the age of majority, and with the voices of people who stop by to make purchases from her. They choose her because of the variety of colours they can find and the selection of clothes she offers at all prices and in many different sizes.

She has so many customers shopping at her home that the space at her home is already too small for the business. As a result, she has decided to join a women's group that shares her same drive to succeed in business so that she can search for a spacious storefront from which to sell her outfits. It is for this reason that she is requesting a loan in order to purchase threads and other materials. She will be able to continue following her dreams as a businesswoman and as the breadwinner for her family.

loans.use: to buy threads and other materials.

loans.name: Sidony's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est créé depuis mai 2007,il est composé de membres qui habitent la même zone et qui sont liées par une responsabilité solidaire.Elles ont comme activité la vente de fruits et de légumes.

Marie qui se trouve à l'extrême droite de la photo en position assise et levant le bras,est l'emprunteuse vedette,elle est mariée,est âgée de 29 ans et mére de 03 enfants.

Son activité est le commerce de bananes,oranges et mangues.Elle pratique ce type de vente depuis l'âge de 16 ans.

Elle compte acheter avec le crédit,03 sacs de bananes pour 50000f,5 caisses de mangues à 5000f la caisse et 04 sacs d'orange à 10000f le sac.

Son objectif est d'assurer la scolarité de ses 02 enfants qui sont à l'école actuellement et augmenter son épargne.
texts.en: This group was created in May 2007. It consists of members who live in the same area and who are bound by joint liability.  They are in the business of selling fruits and vegetables.  Marie, who is sitting at the far right of the photo with her arm raised, is the group representative.  She is married, 29 years old, and mother of three children.  She sells bananas, oranges, and mangoes.  She has been in this business since the age of 16.  With this loan, she plans to buy 3 bags of bananas for 50,000 francs, 5 boxes of mangoes for 5,000 francs, and four bags of oranges for 10,000 francs per bag.  Her goal is to pay for the school fees of her two children who are currently attending school and to increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy 3 bags of bananas, 5 boxes of mangoes, and 4 bags of oranges.

loans.name: Hanatu

texts.en: Hanatu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Hanatu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her  children: Bilya, Nafisa, and  Lois. Hanatu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Hanatu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Hanatu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Hanatu is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that her longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: La'azaru

texts.en: La'azaru is a 50-year-old farmer from Makera.  As a Babban Gona member, La'azaru is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, La'azaru can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, La'azaru is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  La'azaru is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children:  Yunusa,  Daniel,  and  Zachariah. La'azaru’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield
